ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The class is valuable for understanding both the mechanisms of the trading system and the wider debates around its efficacy and legitimacy.

Q1. Many readings were published in late '90s/early '00s which did always best inform the subject we were discussing in the course. Outdated documents from these periods are a great way to understand the frame of mind policy -makers were in when making important policy decisions. Considering the quite significant reading load for the course, it may be most valuable to pare down some of the older readings and replace them with updated material. Q2. memo-style assignments were excellent and a great way to reinforce important lecture concepts. Also am in favor of the 2 memo requirement. Suggestion: increase number of memos to 3 and count for 30% to reduce the weight of final exam. This would encourage students to complete memos earlier in the semester, therefore read more material and contribute more to lecture discussions. Q8-10. Dan Esty was superb at facilitating class discussion in a non-intimidating manner, which put the class at ease. Elena was a great TA, was responsive to email and very engaged with students.
The professor's professional experiences brought a great practical aspect to instruction.

Question 10: After taking undergraduate and graduate courses at Yale for 6 years, I believe Professor Esty is one of the best professors at Yale. Conversations are interesting, engaging, and lucid. This was a subject material I had no background in, but feel much more aware and comfortable with it. Even if trade is not your focus (it wasn't mine), I highly recommend this class, because you'll get the best explanation possible for a subject that greatly influences the world we live in.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The constant interaction between the professor and the students.
The engaging nature of the class (conversations flowed freely and there was active discussion about the issues)
Clear, well planned lectures with space for meaningful discussion and a wide range of opinions from classmates.
Very clear lectures - one of the clearest instructors I have had here. I enjoyed the lively seminar style discussions as well.

Professor Esty clearly has a mastery of the subject and related fields. His real world experience in the field helped to solidify some of the concepts and underlying issues that we dealt with in the class.
Class discussions, the openness of the professors to different opinions and suggestions
A very diverse classroom with thoughtful discussions led by Professor Esty.
1. Prof. Esty 2. Discussion based class 3. Wide coverage (through various topics)

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More policy memo topic, more guest speakers

Sometimes clarity came at the expense of not exploring the complexity. Also, the course and/or instructors use the GATT as the starting point, but it would have enriched the class to do a brief (abridged) history of trade to contextualize the trading system in the history of trade. Otherwise, the class discussions often leaned heavily toward simple economistic models, which some students presumed as a sort of 'natural law'.
Some of the materials were very extensive and the detail and scope of the readings did not always match with the pace of the class which was quick with a broad amount of topics to cover.

I would like to see more focus on the legal aspects of international trade. It felt like the course was more focused on issues of international political economy than law. Also, some of the readings could be updated. In the human rights section I think it would be good to look into the work of John Ruggie as the UN Special Representative on Business and Human Rights.
Everything is perfect.
Scan pages from the international trade law text book. There is no need for students to purchase the whole thing

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes. Professor Esty is amazing.
Yes. Perfect balance of theory, practice and discussion.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm a student in the International & Development Economics program and this course helps to provide a law perspective on the two issues we study in my course.

Trade law has provided me with an important understanding of the broad and technical aspects of the global trading system. As an F&ES student, I see this as a critical part of a well-rounded education in the global forces shaping resource use.

I study the link between trade and land use in land intensive commodity chains (timber, agriculture, mineral extraction). It was very helpful to have a sort of technical course on trade law that also pushed students to think about future reforms or solutions to the system.
Policy is one of my focus areas. This course gives the perfect foundation of international trade. This base is essential to formulate any policy.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this class because of my interested in the WTO and international trade in general.
I wanted to know more about the international trade law processes and some of the pertinent issues in trade
I took this course to improve my understanding of international systems of trade, their drivers and their challenges.
This was the only course that deals with international trade law.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely.
Yes.

Yes, mostly. It would have been interesting to have more readings on the empirical research that evaluate the trade claims made - e.g., whether or not policy A led to real wage increases in country X or sector Y.
Yes. I gained a good understanding of the international trading system and the class provided me with insight into avenues to pursue if a more in depth coverage of some of the materials is desired.
Yes. Beyond my expectations.
Yes. It was way beyond expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The whole class can be viewed as group discussions.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would recommend taking the course!
This is a valuable course for whoever interested in international environmental issues.
Never miss any lecture.. there is so much to learn.
It's a good course if they're interesting in the subject. Lots of readings.
See my answer above
